awd_titl_txt: Two + Three Community College to University Programs Scholars Project
awd_abstract_narration: This project is providing needed-based scholarships to qualified students participating in an innovative partnership between Norfolk State University Engineering faculty and peer faculty at five community college campuses. The project extends the conventional focus of college transfer programs beyond the baccalaureate to the graduate level.  The project includes comprehensive enrichment activities to cultivate social and intellectual connections between participating students and faculty across six college campuses. These activities include a bridge immersion program, peer mentoring and tutorial services, weekend recruiting events, and a televideo seminar series. The project increases the number of talented students, including female and minority students, in the targeted Electronics and Optical Engineering program. Assessments are being conducted to identify and document factors that influence student success and partnership strength.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of the Norfolk State Uiversity (NSU) Two-Three Community College to University Programs Project (TCUP) Scholarship effort has been to amplify community college pathways into engineering careers. Five interdependent themes formed the core program design, 

1)   Academic enrichment;

2)   Marketing and networking;

3)   Community-building activities;

4)   Outreach; and

5)   Assessment.

The prmary community college targets for the project included Central Virginia Community College (Lynchburg, VA), Northern Virginia Community College (Alexandria, VA), The College of Southern Maryland (LaPlata, MD), Thomas Nelson Community College (Newport News, VA), and Tidewater Community College (Norfolk, VA). 

The TCUP project has had a significant impact on the culture and morale of the Engineering department students and faculty, as evidenced through interviews and focus groups conducted at the close of the fifth year of the effort. The students report that their participation was an "unexpected benefit" of attendance at NSU for the baccalaureate degree. The focussed attention of faculty and opportunity to immediately join a community of students with similar needs helped them to experience a strong connection to the NSU community. The program activity for which students expressed the most appreciation was community outreach, with particular appreciation for the connection between NSU and the FIRST Robotics program efforts.  Finally, the TCUP scholars valued the program becuase it gave them a chance to "fill the role of being a scholar" and it gave their family members a reason to experience a sense of pride through their accomplishment.

Faculty interviewees reported that they were"surprised at the level of enthusiasm and participation" of the transfer students. The faculty noted that the contributions of TCUP students were as visible as those from students that had been at the university throughout their freshman and sophomore years. TCUP scholars also have led efforts to renew student chapter of IEEE (Institute for Elecrical and Electronics Engineers), the dominant professional society for practicing electrical engineers.

At the start of the project, the newly formed programs in Electrical and Optical engineering had only scant participation of community college transferees. By the close of the effort, the transfer enrollment for all engineering students at the second-year and higher was 19.67%. Transfer students also represented 31% of the graduating engineering students in May 2016, and the graduation figure is expected to be 20% in May 2017. 

The engineering department hopes to sustain the positive transfer student culture through a targeted set of acitvities that have been implemented following a program evaluation activity that was completed in spring 2016. These include formation of a formal student group for transfer students in engineering, continuation of dedicated academic advisors for transfer students, continuation of targeted outreach and social activities, and targeted programming to engage community college faculty in NSU research efforts.  The faculty will also continue its aggressive recruitment efforts with Virginia Community College System schools, but the greatest emphasis will be on the Hapmton Roads area campuses of  Tidewater Community College and Thomas Nelson Community College. 


Last Modified: 05/20/2016
Modified by: Patricia F Mead
